event.desce:
SALONEN | Castor GRIEG | Piano Concerto in A minor, op. 16 SIBELIUS | LemminkÃ¤inen Suite, op. 22
â€œThe Finnish conducting miracleâ€ â€“ Tagesspiegel
Tarmo Peltokoski, Music Director Designate of the HK Phil, leads a captivating Nordic-inspired programme that showcases Finland in both its traditional and cosmopolitan forms. The evening opens with Castor, a dazzling orchestral work by Esa-Pekka Salonen, HK Philâ€™s Composer-in-Residence for the 2025/26 season and a compatriot and mentor of Peltokoski. The piece is inspired by the twin brothers of Greek mythology, Castor and Pollux. (Peltokoski will also conduct the companion piece, Pollux, in July 2026.) Superstar pianist Lang Lang then brings radiant virtuosity to Griegâ€™s lyrical Piano Concerto, before the concert concludes with Sibeliusâ€™s LemminkÃ¤inen Suite, evoking the mythic heart of Finnish folklore in all its power and poetry.
event.presenterorge: Hong Kong Philharmonic Orchestra

event.desce:
Adapted from Hong Kongâ€™s Award-winning Original Musical Field of Dreams
Pays Tribute to a Classic with a Brand-New Interpretation
One Header beats Ten Opponents â€“ Reliving Hong Kongâ€™s Football Legacy with Passion!
In the summer of 1936, China participated in the Olympics for the first time with a football team largely composed of players from Hong Kong. Led by Asiaâ€™s Football King, Lee Wai-tong, a group of passionate local players from Lo Wai, a small fishing village in Tai Hang, Hong Kong, joined forces with players from China to form the national team. They prepared for the event and raised funds during a highly successful tour of Southeast Asia.
Amidst national turmoil, war, conflicts and disparity between class and identity, ideals and reality, and city and community, not to mention the financial struggles of football clubs, a group of fervent young footballers persevered on the field of their dreams. With faith and determination to overcome adversity, they showcased their signature move â€“ the Ding Tau Chui (header). Their resilience led them to the Berlin Olympics in Germany, making history as the first Chinese national football team to compete on the international stage.

event.desce:
Sharing love and joy with over 110,000 guests since 2021
Celebrating this Hong Kong Adventureâ€™s 5th Anniversary
Leap into the holiday spirit and twirl through a Hong Kong winter wonderland!
In its glorious 5th year celebrating 100 fabulous performances, Septime Webreâ€™s heartwarming The Nutcracker: A Hong Kong Adventure with Tchaikovskyâ€™s timeless score returns to delight audiences of all ages in an exciting Christmas Eve adventure! Clara, Fritz and the Nutcracker Prince set out to defeat the sinister Rat King to restore order to their magical kingdom, and along the way they meet Hong Kongâ€™s vibrant peacocks, spirited racing jockeys, twirling dim sum, breathtaking bauhinias and more. Audiences will be thrilled by surprising new elements in this yearâ€™s enthralling production. With scores of glittering costumes and extraordinary sets, this enchanting classic captures the wonder of childhood and victory over evil as it celebrates early 20th century Hong Kongâ€™s history, characters and natural beauty.
In 2024, The Nutcracker notably won UNESCOâ€™s Star of Outstanding Award and the Spirit of Culture Award at the 12th Spirit of Hong Kong Awards.

event.titlee: Hong Kong Pop Culture Festival 2025:Comic Fun for Allâ€”The Magic of Hong Kong Comedy Comics
event.predateE: 21/05/2025(Wed)-09/03/2026(Mon) Remarks: Closed on Tue (except public holidays) and the first two days of the Chinese New Year
event.desce:
Taking the perspective of comic artists, this exhibition will open the door to the magical world of comics by showcasing exhibits associated with Hong Kong comedy comics from different periods, including manuscripts, comic books, comic byproducts, art installations and multimedia programmes. Visitors can take photos with comic characters from different periods and gain insights into the inspiration of comic artists. This retrospective of important works that have amused us from the 1950s to the present will bring to life the unique charm of Hong Kong comedy comics, as well as their creative concepts and artistic features.
Jointly presented by the Leisure and Cultural Services Department and the Hong Kong Comics & Animation Federation
Jointly organised by the Hong Kong Heritage Museum and the Hong Kong Comics & Animation Federation
Sponsored by: Cultural and Creative Industries Development Agency (CCIDA)

event.desce:
Hong Kong filmmakers and film workers of its golden age formed deep bonds with each other. Kindred spirits often became sworn brothers and sisters as an expression of their friendship and appreciation for each other. Such legendary alliances include â€˜The Seven Idlesâ€™, a group of elite behind-the-scenes crew in the 1950s; the â€˜Eight Peoniesâ€™, consisting of celebrated opera performers in the 1960s; and the opera starlets known for playing second female leads erbang huadans, who became the â€˜Nine Big Sistersâ€™. In 1965, seven young actressesâ€”who all started out as child actors and were brought together by their shared journey in filmâ€”formed a sisterhood known as the famous â€˜Seven Princessesâ€™.
The Seven Princesses, in order of seniority, were Fung So-bor, Shum Chi-wah, Connie Chan Po-chu, Josephine Siao Fong-fong, Nancy Sit Kar-yin, Wong Oi-ming, and Fungâ€™s younger sibling, Fung Bo-bo. Each a star in her own right, these seven actresses often collaborated onscreen, and have shared an intimate, enduring sisterly bond offscreen for six decades.
In commemoration of their 60th anniversary, the Hong Kong Film Archive presents a special programme, â€˜Youthful Imprintsâ€™, spotlighting the early works of the Seven Princesses, including those made before and after their bond. Fifteen films will be screened across four categories: â€˜Commemoration of Sisterhoodâ€™, â€˜Signature Worksâ€™, â€˜Youthful Loveâ€™, and â€˜Shadows of Grace and Intrigueâ€™.
Though the seven actresses have appeared in many films in various pairings from a young age, only one film featured all of them together: Seven Princesses. This film, along with its sequel will be screened as part of â€˜Commemoration of Sisterhoodâ€™. â€˜Signature Worksâ€™ features one representative film per princess, showcasing defining moments of breakthrough in their careers, such as Connie Chanâ€™s first lead role in a contemporary drama You Do Me Wrong (1966) and Nancy Sitâ€™s debut as leading lady in Bunny Girl (1967). In the late 1960s, as the princesses grew up into young women, they stepped into roles that captured youthful dreams and romantic longing, as befitting their maidenly images. The four films in â€˜Youthful Loveâ€™ alternate between charming and bittersweet tales of love, highlighting this period in the princessesâ€™ careers. Finally, â€˜Shadows of Grace and Intrigueâ€™ captures the princessesâ€™ martial prowess. Connie Chan, Josephine Siao and Shum Chi-wah trained under Peking opera master Fen Ju Hua, and their Northern-style martial arts skills are on full display in the selected action films, where they deliver unforgettable performances as heroines in costumes.
The Archive has digitally scanned some selected films, which will be screened for the first time as part of this programme, offering cinephiles enhanced audio-visual quality. Select screenings will also feature post-screening talks with members of the Seven Princesses and film critics.

event.desce:
Unleash your child's boundless creativity through the arts! Led by professional artists, the Arts for Fun family workshop bridges diverse art forms to provide fresh perspectives and stimulate creative minds! Unlock your childâ€™s creative potential with two exciting themes, â€œDrama x Visual Artsâ€ and â€œDance x Photographyâ€, and create unique artwork together!
Drama x Visual Arts 29 & 30/11/2025 (Sat & Sun) Tutors: Dominic Lee & Margaret Chu
Dance x Photography 6 & 7/12/2025 (Sat & Sun) Tutors: Liz Tsui & Thomas Lin
For children aged 6+ and their parents In Cantonese

event.desce:
In the 1970s, bass was often relegated to an accompaniment role. However, talented bassist Jaco Pastorius, with his exceptional playing technique, innovative chords, and tonal developments, transformed the instrument into a leading musical presence. Whether in his fusion jazz band Weather Report or in his personal musical journey, his playing was captivating. Although this prodigy passed away at the young age of 35, he remains etched in the hearts of music fans as one of the greatest bassists of all time.
In this concert, Japanese bass master Tetsuo Sakurai will pay tribute to this American legend by reinterpreting his classic pieces. Sakurai was a core member of the band Casiopea, infusing the group with vibrant bass performances, and later embarked on a solo career that has taken him to over twenty countries. Now, he will come to Hong Kong to honor the genius bassist Jaco Pastorius with his superb artistry.
event.presenterorge: Jazz World & Count-In Music

event.desce: Hiromi, a national treasure-level jazz pianist in Japan, has won many heavyweight honors in her music career, including the Grammy Award and the Japan Record Award. Her performance and composition skills have long been highly recognized by the industry. The band she leads also has extraordinary members, including trumpeter Adam Oâ€™Farrill, who has been recognized by Downbeat magazine twice, as well as the skilled French bassist Hadrien FÃ©raud and Chicago drummer Gene Coye. The music of this band is very tense, combining jazz, rock, electronic and other musical elements together to form a unique musical expression that is difficult to define with conventional styles.

event.desce:
Why do the roles of mothers, maids and villainess often fall into the as mezzo-soprano range? And why are leading roles so often written for tenors and sopranos? Do basses ever get the chance to be the â€œleading manâ€? Each of us has a voice thatâ€™s uniquely our own, with its own tone, colour and personality.
In Western classical music, voices are generally divided into four categories: soprano, alto, tenor and bass. That is just a rough guide based on vocal range, but in fact, there is a lot more to it than that. Some go further, looking into tone quality, vocal colour, tessitura, resonance, and even how a roleâ€™s dramatic demands shape the choice of voice. That is why we end up with all sorts of labels like coloratura, lyric, buffo, dramatic and heroic, making the world of voices wonderfully rich and full of surprises.
In the Vocal Lecture Series: The Human Voice in 4 Parts, the speaker will lead participants on a journey through the four main voice types (in the order of B, A, S, T) to explore how each one brings a different kind of character to life on the opera stage. We will look at how composers decide which voice suits which role, and get to know some of the great singers who have become legends in their respective categories. Together, we will discover what makes their voices so distinctive and enjoy some of their unforgettable performances. Curator / Speaker: Chan Siu-kwan
7 Jan 2026 (Wed) Lecture 1: Bass Is every man who canâ€™t hit high notes automatically a bass? Well, not quite. Between the tenor and the bass lies the baritone, and even that can be further divided into high and low baritones. Weâ€™ll find out what makes them different, and whether baritones or basses ever get to be the â€œleading manâ€.
14 Jan 2026 (Wed) Lecture 2: Alto Why do the roles of mothers, maids and villainesses so often fall into the mezzo-soprano or contralto range? And what are countertenors? They are fascinating male singers who sound almost like female altos? Weâ€™ll find out.
21 Jan 2026 (Wed) Lecture 3: Soprano Why is the soprano so often the â€œleading ladyâ€? And does she always have to be the â€œgoodâ€ one? Whether noble and elegant, tender and heartbroken, or strong and commanding â€” the soprano voice leaves her mark on every kind of role imaginable.
28 Jan 2026 (Wed) Lecture 4: Tenor In the great Italian operas of the Romantic era, the leading man is almost always a tenor. What makes this voice type so irresistibly charming? And why is the famous â€œHigh Câ€ such a prized gift among tenors?
(Information provided by the speaker)
Conducted in Cantonese. Each lecture will run for about 1 hour and 30 minutes. Free seating. The programme does not represent the views of the Leisure and Cultural Services Department. The presenter reserves the right to change the programme.
